title: 107_s1685
content: The Act titled "Kids and Terrorism Preparedness Act" mandates emergency medical and rescue services for children. The "Kids and Terrorism Preparedness Act" mandates grants or contracts to improve emergency medical services for children, including trauma and critical care, with a focus on injury prevention activities and data collection. The amendment extends the program duration from 3 to 4 years and adjusts the timeline for implementation. Authorization of $45,000,000 for section 1910 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to change "4th" to "5th". SEC. 3. APPROPRIATE MEDICINES FOR CHILDREN IN THE FACE OF BIOTERRORISM. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will convene meetings with manufacturers to develop new countermeasures for children exposed to biological agents and toxins. They will also give public notice of products that should be studied in response to bioterrorist threats. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award contracts, grants, or cooperative agreements to conduct studies related to children in response to bioterrorist threats. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 4. CHILDREN'S MENTAL HEALTH. Amends Section 501(m) of the Public Health Service Act to increase funds for emergency mental health and substance abuse treatment for children affected by terrorist acts. SEC. 5. CRISIS RESPONSE GRANTS TO ADDRESS CHILDREN'S NEEDS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants to address children's needs in response to bioterrorist threats. SEC. 5. Crisis response grants to address children's needs in response to bioterrorist threats. The Secretary may award grants to eligible entities to increase coordination and development of bioterrorism preparedness efforts for children. Eligible entities include States, political subdivisions, non-profit agencies, or organizations serving children. Grants must be used for activities related to coordination. The Secretary may award grants for bioterrorism preparedness efforts for children, using funds from the 2001 Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act.
